ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We were challenged to think about human history in an extremely big-picture way (ex: I had never, before this class, considered whether the Agricultural Revolution was a good or a bad thing for humanity. Spoiler alert: probably bad). And to critically assess historical claims and arguments from several angles (both evidential and conceptual).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: really brilliant professor who knows a lot and is so kind, and there was thoughtful and careful analysis of the books.

Weaknesses: The conversation often felt unstructured, and how good a class discussion was often felt like it depended on how many of us had done the reading thoroughly that week (meaning that it wasn't always all of us. I am as guilty of that as anyone, but it actually did make class worse).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! You really can enjoy this class (and bring something to the discussion) no matter what you study -- for a history class, it's very interdisciplinary. And it's fun! You get to read some good books and laud them, some bad books and trash them, and talk about what makes books good and bad -- you think differently about the practice of history after taking this course, I think.
